channel.title: BBC News - Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Gun owners' fears after firearms dealer data breach
item.description: Thousands of records from the popular shotgun and rifle sales site Guntrader were posted to the dark web.

item.title: More than 600,000 people told to isolate by NHS Covid-19 app
item.description: 618,903 people in England and Wales received self-isolation alerts in the week up to 14 July

item.title: Major websites hit by global outage
item.description: The websites of HSBC, British Airways and Airbnb are among those to have briefly gone offline.

item.title: California sues Activision Blizzard over alleged harassment
item.description: One of the world's largest gaming companies is accused of endemic discrimination and harassment.

item.title: Pegasus spyware seller: Blame our customers, not us, for hacking
item.description: NSO Group tells BBC News: "The finger-pointing should be at the customer."

item.title: Twitter trials upvote and downvote buttons
item.description: Some iOS users will see thumb and arrow buttons as the company experiments with voting.

item.title: Mike Lynch: UK extradition treaty doesn't rely on any facts
item.description: Autonomy's founder, Mike Lynch, says he will fight the US authorities' bid to try him for fraud.

item.title: Call for online abusers to be reported to bosses
item.description: A group is calling for companies to set up ways for people to report workers behaving abusively online.

item.title: Stinky Bay? Local names added to map to aid coastal rescue
item.description: Local names for coastal places are added to OS maps to help rescuers locate those in need.

item.title: Senior US Catholic resigns over Grindr allegations
item.description: A newsletter obtains mobile app data allegedly showing a Roman Catholic official used Grindr and visited gay bars.

item.title: Hackers reportedly demand $50m from Saudi Aramco over data leak
item.description: The world's most valuable oil producer confirmed to the BBC that company files had been leaked.

item.title: British man arrested in Spain over Twitter hack
item.description: The 2020 attack on a series of celebrity accounts targeted Elon Musk and Barack Obama, among others.

item.title: Cyber-flashing: 'I get explicit messages every day'
item.description: Influencer Elle Edwards lets us inside her DMs to show the extent of sexual abuse faced by women online.

item.title: Spyware: The software that watches you
item.description: BBC’s cyber reporter, Joe Tidy, agreed to be spied on to understand the spyware experience further.

item.title: Custom glasses: Will 3D-printing change our eyewear?
item.description: Eyewear can be more tailored to an individual’s face producing a better fit and reduce overstocking.

item.title: Robot helps people get dressed and other tech news
item.description: Romana Kreider looks at some of the best technology news stories of the week.

item.title: Duran Duran’s Invisible: 'Thrilled' with AI collaboration
item.description: Musician Nick Rhodes explains why artificial intelligence was key in making their new music video.

item.title: What does a future-proofed home look like?
item.description: The technology exists to make homes more resilient to extreme weather, but it can be expensive.

item.title: Zoomtown-on-Sea? The lure of a new life on the coast
item.description: Remote working meant the Lancaster family could live anywhere - they found their sea view in Scarborough.

item.title: Pegasus scandal: Are we all becoming unknowing spies?
item.description: We may be stepping into a world in which we are all spies - and at the same time are all spied on.

item.title: Finding 'Grace': Murder, DNA and ancestry
item.description: How a novel use of DNA and ancestry websites is helping police uncover clues in cold case murders.

item.title: Why was my tweet about football labelled abusive?
item.description: A BBC journalist sets out to discover how Twitter moderates posts after he was banned from the platform.

item.title: Pegasus: Who are the alleged victims of spyware targeting?
item.description: Jamal Khashoggi's wife and the editor of the Financial Times are among those said to be targeted.
